results.title: Point of entry
results.creator_credit: Jack Rogers, Peter Johnson, Film Australia and Plant Quarantine Publicity Campaign
results.brief_description: In order to keep unwanted pests out of Australia, constant vigilance must be maintained at points of entry. This film deals mainly with the dangers to plants and crops if precautions are not exercised, and shows some of the methods taken to safeguard Australia’s plant life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack Rogers, Peter Johnson, Film Australia and Plant Quarantine Publicity Campaign

results.title: Point of departure
results.brief_description: This compelling and sensitive dramatic portrayal of writer and political activist Jean Devanney provides an interesting view of Australia between the wars and the roles of the new literary scene during that period. The film dramatises sequences which examine Devanney’s important friendships with other women writers, notably Miles Franklin, Susannah Pritchard and Marjorie Barnard. A rebellious woman, Devanney was unable to resolve her conflicting roles of mother, writer and communist party member. She wrote political novels while also publishing “pot boilers” to support her family. Her first book “The Butcher’s Shop” with its theme of women’s rights to sexual and economic freedom was banned in New Zealand.

results.title: Point of danger: agriculture's first line of defence
results.creator_credit: Eric Thompson and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: An insight into the work of quarantine officers inspecting imports from abroad to detect plant diseases and insect pests which may bring ruin and destruction to Australian agriculture if introduced into this country.
results.title_for_label: Point of danger: agriculture’s first line of defence

results.title: Point of contact
results.brief_description: Shows the work that ordinary untrained volunteers do as opposed to trained professionals in helping the mentally ill. Shows the Personal Emergency Service in operaiton, and how specially trained volunteers man the telephone and answer calls for help. Dr Dax tells how volunteers help rehabilitate the mentally ill at the Kew Mental Hospital (Kew Cottages?) and their work is illustrated. Written and introduced by Anthony Evans.

results.title: Point break [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Kathryn Bigelow, Robert L Levy, Peter Abrams and Largo Entertainment
results.brief_description: Kathryn Bigelow’s (Strange Days, Blue Steel) fourth feature is a study of masculinity and surfer culture. Johnny Utah (Keanu Reeves) is a rookie FBI agent working undercover trying to crack an elite group of bank robbers who wear masks of ex-Presidents to hide their identities. As the criminals are thought to belong to an exclusive surfer cult, Utah learns to surf to infiltrate the group. Utah selects Tyler (Lori Petty), who is unaware of his true identity, to teach him the breaks that will make him a convincing surfer and keep his cover sound. Utah meets Bodhi (Patrick Swayze) a top surfer and adrenalin junkie, for whom surfing has a spiritual and mythical significance. “Point Break” is an action film that contains some impressive stunts including car chases, leaps from aeroplanes, exploding petrol stations and memorable scenes of breaking waves. Reeves is interestingly cast as the straight-laced policeman who has to learn the speech and mannerisms of a stoner dude. Filmed in Hawaii, California, Oregon and Bondi Beach, New South Wales.

results.title: Point blank
results.creator_credit: John Boorman, Judd Bernard and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Based on Donald E. Westlake’s novel “The Hunter”, Lee Marvin stars as an amoral and apathetic antihero in this stylish landmark thriller. Walker (Marvin) is a professional criminal who helps pull off an underworld heist, then is double-crossed, gunned down and left for dead on deserted Alcatraz Island. But he resurface in Los Angeles to track down his share of the loot. Aided by an accomplice (Angie Dickinson), he takes on the syndicate at it’s own deadly game, doggedly stalking his prey across the ever-changing backdrop of seething ‘60s L.A. The trail piles twist upon twist as it leads Walker to a cunning mobman (Carroll O’Connor) and a surprise ending. Remade in 1999 as “Payback” starring Mel Gibson.

results.title: Poil de Carotte = Red Head
results.brief_description:
In rural France, ‘Poil de Carotte’, an undernourished and unloved young boy, is badly treated by is ageing mother but his often absent father is unaware of all this. Everything comes to a head when the boy attempts suicide. The film opens a stunning establishing shot, nearly two minutes long and containing eleven distinct movements. ‘Poil de Carotte’ was filmed by Julien Duvivier in 1926 (silent). It was re-made by Paul Mesnier (1952) and Henri Graziani (1973).

Credits: Director, Julien Duvivier ; writers, Julien Duvivier, Jules Renard ; photography, Armand Thirard, Emile Monniot ; music, Alexandre Tansman ; art direction, Lucien Aguettant, Lucien Carre.
Cast: Harry Baur, Robert Lynen, Louis Gauthier, Catherine Fontenay.

results.title: Poetry for me
results.brief_description: An original method of presenting children’s poetry. Introduces the fundamental ideas of rhythm, imagery, and word sounds. Shows that poetry is wonderfully descriptive, using all the aspects of language to communicate meaning with feeling. Develops the idea that poetry stimulates a greater appreciation of surroundings.

results.title: Poetry for fun: trulier coolier
results.brief_description: This film features eight poems, chosen by children and dealing with what children do, what they think about, and how they feel about their world. Included are animated cartoons, giant puppets, creative photography and music. Suitable for lower and upper primary levels.
